If you think the ENVIRONMENT, TOGETHER WITH THE EARTH, is less important than the economic growth, try to hold your breath while you are counting your money. HOW LONG CAN YOU BEAR IT?

Dear Friends and Acquaintances,

I would like to ask everyone who is interested at least a little bit in the environment, to promote my campaign to their friends and acquaintances. I do not want anything from you to start the processing plant, just $ 1, but if someone sends more, I will thank for it. If one cannot contribute to it, I understand, but then please at least like or forward my message. If you have any questions, please write me to the following address: wasteprocessinghu@gmail.com. I will constantly upload pictures and videos in order to introduce you this technology!

Thanks to everyone in advance,

Csaba Wágner, Mihály Szivássy, Péter Csordás

<td>
General waste,
containing plastic, baby diapers, car tires, mixed vegetable waste, glass,
traces of textiles, mainly plastic textiles, cases of computers, etc. causes
a big problem in all countries oft he world. What about coming up with an
already existing technology that is able to combine all these and create a
material, a new product which can be used for the creation of various
objects? YES, YOU ARE RIGHT, it is able to crumple all these in a
thermo-chemical way. The end product could be used, for instance, for the
production of street benches, columns used for game protection along
highways, tanks which can be used as pontoon bridges, or for the construction
of dams. The possibilities are endless. The waste can be processed including
all types of waste, except for metals. The new material is odorless,
unbreakable and durable. Do not tell me that you have never thought of finding
a solution for this problem? This is why I am writing you, as I am not asking
for your help but your financial support to be able to complete our project.
In which phase are we currently with the implementation? Right in the middle
of it. The research work of several years has been completed with a budget of
lots of dollars, the prototype of the machine has been prepared, too
take a look at it during its operation, and in Hungary the experimental
product was manufactured exclusively from waste. We aim to establish a
joint-stock company, in order to have the chance to manufacture lots of such
kind of machines in series, particularly with higher performance. I would
like to thank you in advance for your help and please note that I am not the
only one behind this project, but there are also some older people who do not
wish to participate in front of the public. I have all the powers and I have
already concluded some contracts, as well. We do not wish to sell the idea.
Please e-mail me what would you like to receive in exchange for your support.
Do not think about big things. If you have any questions, I am ready to
answer by e-mail due to language-related difficulties.
Thank you for
reading my introduction,
Sincerely,
Csaba Wágner
</tr>
</tbody>

<td>
What is the risk to
the business? Just like in case of any business, it has a risk, too
bureaucracy. Probably you have already met problems when you wanted to
resolve something, you knew that it was easy but bureaucracy intervened and
you could not find a solution? This is the case here, as well, but our main
problem is money as we have ran out of it. It is true that everything can be
resolved with money. On the other hand, however, it is not always good if we
settle problems with money. We need your support because we will not be at
the mercy of bureaucracy if we have our own independent sources of money.
Here you come into the picture with your support. In one year’s time I would
like to be able to talk about a „realized funded project“ of the company.
</tr>
</tbody>

Dear helpful people from all over the world! I would like to express my thanks to those people who selflessly help in our environmental project. Through me,  your support will be forwarded in full to ....... I hope that the many years of research will not be wasted and as a result of your support we can create a cleaner environment.

Thank you, Wágner, Szilvássy, Csordás

column5: >Tuqtuquilal means 'Harmony' In Q'eqchi Mayan. It is an Impact Center located in the lush jungle of Lanquin, Alta Verapaz, Guatemala, on 56 acres of fertile, but partly degenerated land. Tuqtuquilal is a center focused on education and is at the heart of a holistic project which aims to inspire regeneration through the development of an intentional village and wellness center.
column6: > Discover more by visiting our website : http://tuqtuquilal.com
column9: >At Tuqtuquilal we believe that there can never be enough trees.
column10: > Trees and the vast biodiversity that they nurture  reduce climate change and support healthy ecosystems, providing us with food, oxygen, and prevent soil erosion.
column11: >We give you the opportunity to plant more trees today and help us make reforestation a priority  that brings hope for us all...... make a regenerative donation, sprouting life from your generosity!
column15: >Here in the valley of Lanquin in Guatemala, we can daily observe  the jungle being reduced  to make space for more monoculture, animal rearing and  construction.
column16: > The removal of trees is creating many problems. First of all, it is a great loss of biodiversity as the forests host enormous amounts of life in many forms : vegetal, animal, fungus, micro-organism, etc...
column17: >Deforestation also creates soil erosion, leading to soil degradation, increased flooding,  underground water reserve depletion, animal migration and the general increasing of world temperatures and disasters.
column18: >Our entire world ecosystem is very dependent on its biodiversity, it is our duty to protect it for us all and for generations of people and animls to come. !
column20: >HELP US PREVENT THIS INSANITY!​
column21: >We would love to keep planting more and more trees on a daily basis and dedicate 2 workers specifically for that purpose, offering them a very meaningful job and something that will help and inspire the local community and visitors for many  generations to come.
column22: >More than ever we need funding to pay for local salaries and tree seedlings (we produce many on site but need to diversify species and therefore buy seeds and seedlings).
column27: > We ask for a minimum of $.8 donation per tree which helps cover a salary for a local worker as well as the tree &
column30: >After we receive a donation, the tree will usually be planted between 1 and 15 days .​
column31: >We plant respecting the natural cycle of the moon and seasons as do the local farmers.
column33: >Please choose among the following trees.
column37: >One of the most sacred and traditional trees of Central America
column38: >​The Copal resin is a powerful healer and purifier, with the power to transmute negative energy. Copal aids in physical, mental, and spiritual healing, and environmental clearing.
column39: >The life force within Copal is said to promote fertility, as it is the life force and “blood” of the tree, which makes it a good incense to burn for birthing ceremonies.
column40: >​We use the copal in our cooperative to craft various products like essential oil or incenses.
column44: >At least 10 million years old, a treasure of Mesoamerica,  super food, medicine and delicious treat....​
column45: >"" Food of the gods"" and  an undervalued treasure for the entire world.
column46: >​Cacao is not only one of the healthiest foods in the world, it's also the main ingredient to make one of the most popular treats humanity has ever discovered :
column48: >Our Criollo Cacao trees comes from the beautiful and luxuriant jungle of Guatemala and are some of the highest quality in the world. Most cacao trees in this area  are beautiful ancestral hybrids producing some of the most delicious and highest quality chocolate.
column49: >The tree itself is a wonderful sub-canopy species that keep its leaves all year providing wonderful shelter for a large range of animals, as well as creating shade for ground species and feeding the soil constantly with dead leaves.
column50: >​The trees will take 3 to 5 years to reach maturity and will need the help of taller shade trees like Madre Cacao or Plantain.
column54: >One of the most remarkable leguminous trees growing in the region.
column55: >It is a very sturdy tree capable of growing in almost any kind of damaged soil. It grows very quickly offering it's shade to sub-canopy species and lots of falling leaves for soil health.
column56: >​It is often used to prepare and nurture a new cacao field as the cacao trees need shade to grow and it is a nitrogen fixer, supplying this nutrient to the cacao, and hence gets it´s name  :
column61: >Even though Plantain is a grass and not a tree we decided to offer it here, as it is a fantastic and very useful crop.
column62: >​It is a quick growing crop that produces very sustainable food (ripe plantain is rich in vitamins, fibers &amp
column63: antioxidants,) while the unripe plantain is lower in sugar, more starchy and allows for the production of flour.
column64: >​The plantain leaves have also many uses (for the fermentation of cacao or mulching for example) as well as its ""trunk"" (which is a wonderful resource for many permaculture applications).
column65: >​It also grows pretty tall and therefore creates very useful shade and attracts the flies that pollinate the cacao.
column69: >One of the most loved trees in the world, and with good reason.
column70: >It’s a symbol of strength, morale, resistance and knowledge.
column71: >​The oak is considered a cosmic storehouse of wisdom embodied in its towering strength.
column72: >​Symbolism aside, Oak trees are important for a number of reasons.
column73: >It’s a long-lived tree which can live more than 1000 years and have multiple uses:
column74: >the boiled bark has therapeutic properties.
column75: >Its fruit (acorn) is used to feed livestock and in times of shortage has also been used for human consumption.
column76: >​Amazing for any kind of construction or craft. For both practical purpose or art.
column80: >Another wonderful tropical permaculture pioneer species and valuable timberwood.
column81: >​Cedar is a beautiful hardwood largely used in construction all over the world.
column85: >Relatively fast growing. Caoba is a very good hard wood.
column86: >Very useful and valuable as construction material, its high stature and strong roots makes it very helpful to create a top canopy roof and help prevent erosion as well as reducing undesired winds
column90: >Another tree which is in fact a grass... bamboo is another wonder of nature.

>Los árboles y la vasta biodiversidad que nutren reducen el cambio climático y apoyan ecosistemas saludables, proporcionándonos alimentos, oxígeno y evitando la erosión del suelo.

Te damos la oportunidad de plantar más árboles hoy y ayúdanos a hacer de la reforestación una prioridad que nos brinde esperanza a todos ... ¡haz una donación regenerativa, brotando vida de tu generosidad!
column123:
>Aquí en el valle de Lanquín en Guatemala, podemos observar diariamente cómo la selva se reduce para dar lugar a más monocultivos, cría de animales y construcción.

La tala de árboles está creando muchos problemas. En primer lugar, es una gran pérdida de biodiversidad ya que los bosques albergan enormes cantidades de vida en muchas formas: vegetal, animal, hongos, microorganismos, etc.

La deforestación también crea erosión del suelo, lo que lleva a la degradación del suelo, aumento de las inundaciones, agotamiento de las reservas de agua subterránea, migración de animales y el aumento general de la temperatura mundial y los desastres.

Todo nuestro ecosistema mundial depende en gran medida de su biodiversidad, es nuestro deber protegerlo para todos nosotros y para las generaciones de personas y animales venideros.

¡AYÚDANOS A PREVENIR ESTA LOCURA!

Nos encantaría seguir plantando más y más árboles a diario y dedicar 2 trabajadores específicamente para ese propósito, ofreciéndoles un trabajo muy significativo y algo que ayudará e inspirará a la comunidad local y a los visitantes durante muchas generaciones por venir.

Más que nunca necesitamos fondos para pagar los salarios locales y las plántulas de árboles (producimos muchas en el sitio, pero necesitamos diversificar las especies y, por lo tanto, comprar semillas y plántulas).

Se dice que la fuerza vital dentro de Copal promueve la fertilidad, ya que es la fuerza vital y la ""sangre"" del árbol, lo que lo convierte en un buen incienso para quemar en las ceremonias de nacimiento.
Usamos el copal en nuestra cooperativa para elaborar diversos productos como aceite esencial o inciensos.

","-- ESPAÑOL ABAJO -- The Tuqtuquilal ProjectTuqtuquilal means 'Harmony' In Q'eqchi Mayan. It is an Impact Center located in the lush jungle of Lanquin, Alta Verapaz, Guatemala, on 56 acres of fertile, but partly degenerated land. Tuqtuquilal is a center focused on education and is at the heart of a holistic project which aims to inspire regeneration through the development of an intentional village and wellness center. Discover more by visiting our website : http://tuqtuquilal.com Our reforestation ProgamAt Tuqtuquilal we believe that there can never be enough trees. Trees and the vast biodiversity that they nurture  reduce climate change and support healthy ecosystems, providing us with food, oxygen, and prevent soil erosion.We give you the opportunity to plant more trees today and help us make reforestation a priority  that brings hope for us all...... make a regenerative donation, sprouting life from your generosity! The ProblemHere in the valley of Lanquin in Guatemala, we can daily observe  the jungle being reduced  to make space for more monoculture, animal rearing and  construction. The removal of trees is creating many problems. First of all, it is a great loss of biodiversity as the forests host enormous amounts of life in many forms : vegetal, animal, fungus, micro-organism, etc...Deforestation also creates soil erosion, leading to soil degradation, increased flooding,  underground water reserve depletion, animal migration and the general increasing of world temperatures and disasters.Our entire world ecosystem is very dependent on its biodiversity, it is our duty to protect it for us all and for generations of people and animls to come. ! HELP US PREVENT THIS INSANITY!​We would love to keep planting more and more trees on a daily basis and dedicate 2 workers specifically for that purpose, offering them a very meaningful job and something that will help and inspire the local community and visitors for many  generations to come.More than ever we need funding to pay for local salaries and tree seedlings (we produce many on site but need to diversify species and therefore buy seeds and seedlings). The Solution :​Reforestation !!!​ We ask for a minimum of $.8 donation per tree which helps cover a salary for a local worker as well as the tree & planting.Thank you so much!After we receive a donation, the tree will usually be planted between 1 and 15 days .​We plant respecting the natural cycle of the moon and seasons as do the local farmers. Please choose among the following trees.COPAL Q'eqchi women harvesting CopalOne of the most sacred and traditional trees of Central America​The Copal resin is a powerful healer and purifier, with the power to transmute negative energy. Copal aids in physical, mental, and spiritual healing, and environmental clearing.The life force within Copal is said to promote fertility, as it is the life force and “blood” of the tree, which makes it a good incense to burn for birthing ceremonies.​We use the copal in our cooperative to craft various products like essential oil or incenses. CACAOAt least 10 million years old, a treasure of Mesoamerica,  super food, medicine and delicious treat....​"" Food of the gods"" and  an undervalued treasure for the entire world.​Cacao is not only one of the healthiest foods in the world, it's also the main ingredient to make one of the most popular treats humanity has ever discovered :CHOCOLATE!Our Criollo Cacao trees comes from the beautiful and luxuriant jungle of Guatemala and are some of the highest quality in the world. Most cacao trees in this area  are beautiful ancestral hybrids producing some of the most delicious and highest quality chocolate.The tree itself is a wonderful sub-canopy species that keep its leaves all year providing wonderful shelter for a large range of animals, as well as creating shade for ground species and feeding the soil constantly with dead leaves.​The trees will take 3 to 5 years to reach maturity and will need the help of taller shade trees like Madre Cacao or Plantain. MADRE CACAOOne of the most remarkable leguminous trees growing in the region.It is a very sturdy tree capable of growing in almost any kind of damaged soil. It grows very quickly offering it's shade to sub-canopy species and lots of falling leaves for soil health.​It is often used to prepare and nurture a new cacao field as the cacao trees need shade to grow and it is a nitrogen fixer, supplying this nutrient to the cacao, and hence gets it´s name  :Madre de Cacao (cacao mother). PLANTAINEven though Plantain is a grass and not a tree we decided to offer it here, as it is a fantastic and very useful crop.​It is a quick growing crop that produces very sustainable food (ripe plantain is rich in vitamins, fibers & antioxidants,) while the unripe plantain is lower in sugar, more starchy and allows for the production of flour.​The plantain leaves have also many uses (for the fermentation of cacao or mulching for example) as well as its ""trunk"" (which is a wonderful resource for many permaculture applications).​It also grows pretty tall and therefore creates very useful shade and attracts the flies that pollinate the cacao. OAKOne of the most loved trees in the world, and with good reason.It’s a symbol of strength, morale, resistance and knowledge. ​The oak is considered a cosmic storehouse of wisdom embodied in its towering strength.​Symbolism aside, Oak trees are important for a number of reasons.It’s a long-lived tree which can live more than 1000 years and have multiple uses:the boiled bark has therapeutic properties.Its fruit (acorn) is used to feed livestock and in times of shortage has also been used for human consumption.​Amazing for any kind of construction or craft. For both practical purpose or art. CEDARAnother wonderful tropical permaculture pioneer species and valuable timberwood.​Cedar is a beautiful hardwood largely used in construction all over the world. MAHOGANY / CAOBARelatively fast growing. Caoba is a very good hard wood.Very useful and valuable as construction material, its high stature and strong roots makes it very helpful to create a top canopy roof and help prevent erosion as well as reducing undesired winds BAMBOOAnother tree which is in fact a grass... bamboo is another wonder of nature. Fast growing and with a really strong root system, bamboo can be used in construction, to prevent erosion, or create natural fences.​It grows really tall and providse a very nice a fresh shade as well as covering the ground with its ever falling leaves. TEKOne of the most sort after hard woods in the world. COCONUTAnd the last but not the least...World superstar...The coconut tree needs no introduction!It is resilient, slow growing but carries a high yield of fruits when mature:​The flesh and water content of the coconut are delicious and nutritious but also allows the production of coconut oil used in many applications and products. Thank you for your help & please visit soon! -- ESPAÑOL --El Proyecto TuqtuquilalQue significa 'Armonía' en Q'eqchi Maya. Es un Centro de Impacto ubicado en la exuberante jungla de Lanquín, Alta Verapaz, Guatemala, en 56 acres de tierra fértil, pero parcialmente degenerada. Tuqtuquilal es un centro enfocado en la educación y está en el corazón de un proyecto holístico que tiene como objetivo inspirar la regeneración a través del desarrollo de un pueblo intencional y un centro de bienestar Puede conocer más visitando nuestro sitio web: http://tuqtuquilal.com Nuestro programa de reforestaciónEn Tuqtuquilal creemos que nunca hay suficientes árboles.Los árboles y la vasta biodiversidad que nutren reducen el cambio climático y apoyan ecosistemas saludables, proporcionándonos alimentos, oxígeno y evitando la erosión del suelo.Te damos la oportunidad de plantar más árboles hoy y ayúdanos a hacer de la reforestación una prioridad que nos brinde esperanza a todos ... ¡haz una donación regenerativa, brotando vida de tu generosidad!  El problemaAquí en el valle de Lanquín en Guatemala, podemos observar diariamente cómo la selva se reduce para dar lugar a más monocultivos, cría de animales y construcción.La tala de árboles está creando muchos problemas. En primer lugar, es una gran pérdida de biodiversidad ya que los bosques albergan enormes cantidades de vida en muchas formas: vegetal, animal, hongos, microorganismos, etc.La deforestación también crea erosión del suelo, lo que lleva a la degradación del suelo, aumento de las inundaciones, agotamiento de las reservas de agua subterránea, migración de animales y el aumento general de la temperatura mundial y los desastres.Todo nuestro ecosistema mundial depende en gran medida de su biodiversidad, es nuestro deber protegerlo para todos nosotros y para las generaciones de personas y animales venideros.¡AYÚDANOS A PREVENIR ESTA LOCURA!Nos encantaría seguir plantando más y más árboles a diario y dedicar 2 trabajadores específicamente para ese propósito, ofreciéndoles un trabajo muy significativo y algo que ayudará e inspirará a la comunidad local y a los visitantes durante muchas generaciones por venir.Más que nunca necesitamos fondos para pagar los salarios locales y las plántulas de árboles (producimos muchas en el sitio, pero necesitamos diversificar las especies y, por lo tanto, comprar semillas y plántulas).  La solución :Reforestación !!!We ask for a minimum of $.8 donation per tree which helps cover a salary for a local worker as well as the tree & planting.Thank you so much!After we receive a donation, the tree will usually be planted between 1 and 15 days .​We plant respecting the natural cycle of the moon and seasons as do the local farmers. Le ofrecemos elegir entre los siguientes árboles. COPALMujeres q'eqchi cosechando CopalUno de los árboles más sagrados y tradicionales de CentroaméricaLa resina de Copal es un poderoso sanador y purificador, con el poder de transmutar la energía negativa. Copal ayuda en la curación física, mental y espiritual, y en la limpieza ambiental.Se dice que la fuerza vital dentro de Copal promueve la fertilidad, ya que es la fuerza vital y la ""sangre"" del árbol, lo que lo convierte en un buen incienso para quemar en las ceremonias de nacimiento.Usamos el copal en nuestra cooperativa para elaborar diversos productos como aceite esencial o inciensos. CACAOAl menos 10 millones de años, un tesoro de Mesoamérica, súper comida, medicina y deliciosa golosina ....Una vez comida de los dioses y hoy en día un tesoro infravalorado para el mundo entero.El cacao no solo es uno de los alimentos más saludables del mundo, también es el ingrediente principal para hacer una de las golosinas más populares que la humanidad haya descubierto:¡CHOCOLATE!Nuestros árboles de Cacao Criollo provienen de la hermosa y exuberante selva de Guatemala y son algunos de los de más alta calidad originados en Guatemala. La mayoría de los árboles de cacao en esta área son hermosos híbridos ancestrales que producen algunos de los cacao más deliciosos que se pueden encontrar en el mundo.El árbol en sí es una maravillosa especie de subdosel que mantiene sus hojas todo el año proporcionando un refugio maravilloso para una gran variedad de animales, además de dar sombra a las especies terrestres y alimentar el suelo constantemente con hojas muertas.Los árboles tardarán de 3 a 5 años en alcanzar la madurez y necesitarán la ayuda de árboles de sombra más altos como Madre Cacao o Plátano. MADRE CACAOUno de los árboles leguminosos más notables que crecen por aquí.Es un árbol muy robusto capaz de crecer en casi cualquier tipo de suelo dañado. Crece muy rápido y crece alto mientras se extiende ampliamente, ofreciendo sombra a las especies del sub-dosel y muchas hojas que caen para que el suelo se acumule.Muy a menudo se usa para preparar un nuevo campo de cacao ya que el árbol del cacao necesita sombra para crecer y de ahí tomó su nombre: Madre de Cacao (madre del cacao).También es un fuerte fijador de nitrógeno y muy útil en la construcción. PLÁTANOAunque el plátano es una hierba y no un árbol. Decidimos ofrecerlo aquí de todos modos, ya que es un cultivo fantástico y muy útil.Es un cultivo de crecimiento rápido que produce alimentos muy sostenibles (el plátano maduro es rico en vitaminas, fibras, antioxidantes, etc ...) mientras que el plátano verde es más bajo en azúcar, más almidonado y permite la producción de harina.Las hojas de plátano también tienen muchos usos (para la fermentación del cacao o como mantillo, por ejemplo), así como su ""tronco"" (que es un recurso maravilloso para muchas aplicaciones de permacultura).También crece bastante alto y, por lo tanto, crea una sombra muy útil. ROBLE ENCINOProbablemente los árboles más queridos del mundo, y con razón.Es un símbolo de fuerza, moral, resistencia y conocimiento.El roble se considera un depósito cósmico de sabiduría encarnada en su imponente fuerza.Crece lentamente, pero seguramente a su propio ritmo. El roble a menudo se asocia con el honor, la nobleza y la sabiduría gracias a su tamaño y longevidad.Dejando a un lado el simbolismo, los robles son importantes por varias razones.Es un árbol longevo que puede vivir más de 1000 años y tiene múltiples usos:la corteza hervida tiene propiedades terapéuticas.Su fruto (bellota) se utiliza para la alimentación del ganado y en épocas de escasez también se ha utilizado para el consumo humano.Increíble para cualquier tipo de construcción o artesanía. Tanto para fines prácticos como art.Los robles pueden vivir fácilmente durante siglos CEDROOtra maravillosa especie pionera de la permacultura tropical y valiosa madera maderable.El cedro es una hermosa madera dura que se utiliza principalmente en la construcción en todo el mundo. CAOBA / CAOBADe crecimiento relativamente rápido. Caoba es una madera dura muy buena.Muy útil y valioso como material de construcción, su alta estatura y raíces fuertes lo hacen muy útil para crear un techo de dosel superior y ayudar a prevenir la erosión, así como a reducir los vientos no deseados. BAMBUOtro árbol que de hecho es una hierba ... bambou es otra maravilla de la naturaleza.De crecimiento relativamente rápido y con un sistema de raíces realmente fuerte, el bambou puede usarse para prevenir la erosión o crear cercas naturales.Crece muy alto y proporciona una sombra fresca muy agradable, además de cubrir el suelo con sus hojas siempre caídas.No hace falta decir que es uno de los materiales de construcción más asombrosos y versátiles que podemos usar en la jungla, ¡así que nunca tendríamos demasiado! TEKUna de las maderas duras más cuidadas del mundo.Ese hermoso árbol es un cultivo valioso a largo plazo que puede tardar un tiempo en crecer, pero proporcionará una recuperación considerable en el futuro. COCOY el último pero no menos importante ...Superestrella mundial ...¡El cocotero no necesita presentación!Es resistente, de crecimiento lento, pero produce un alto rendimiento de frutos cuando está maduro:La carne y el contenido de agua del coco son deliciosos y nutritivos, pero lo más importante es que permite la producción de aceite de coco.Uno de los mejores aceites para usar en cualquier aplicación. ¡Muchas gracias por tu ayuda!",26.0,0,"2 Campaigns

Short Summary

While lions, rhinos, and elephants gain mainstream attention in African conservation, there are thousands of species that go unnoticed and unstudied, leaving conservationists with no information on which to base conservation efforts. Unfortunately, this is the case with the Saddlebill Stork (Ephippiorhynchus senegalensis), which has been poorly studied. Even with a lack of data, conservationists have assumed Saddlebills are not threatened, which has resulted in low research priority. New research by this team, however, has found that Saddlebills are not as widespread as has been assumed
column2: and that they are mostly confined to national parks.

column1: As a young ecologist I have become concerned about the implications of this narrative and have made it my career goal to fill scientific knowledge gaps to better inform conservation of overlooked species. The story of this project perfectly demonstrates how science should work: I observed Saddlebill Storks in Zambia, asked questions about them, and designed a study to answer those questions. But it also demonstrates how conservation should NOT work: it has a large geographic range, people see it in many places since it's conspicuous, so conservationists assumed it's unthreatened and made up a number for the population size.

While doing carnivore research in Zambia, I saw the Saddlebill and the mystery surrounding it as an opportunity to (1) answer questions for conserving the species and (2) show how the current approach to assessing conservation status can be very inappropriate. I knew it would be an uphill journey to start a field-based project in Africa from scratch, but I was determined. Over the course of two years and three jobs, I realized the Saddlebill could also be used as an umbrella wetland species, which essentially means it could act as a representative for other wildlife with which it shares its wetland habitat. Therefore, by conserving the Saddlebill and its habitat, you would also be positively affecting hundreds of other species.

Against all odds, the logistical and financial challenges of the project were tackled during the two years following inception thanks to the support of many, especially African Bird Club and Texas State University. In June 2019 we had our first field season in which our primary goal was to put GPS tracking units of five Saddlebills for the first time ever. However, the coincidental timing of the worst drought in 40 years meant very few storks were left in the study area in Liuwa Plain National Park, Zambia. The lack of water from the drought also resulted in significant fishing pressure from local people, which caused prey depletion and direct disturbance of the storks. As a result, we only captured one stork and managed to deploy the first tracking unit ever put on a Saddlebill.
Now that we can better anticipate the challenges in the field, we hope to return to Liuwa Plain in December 2019 to capture four more Saddlebills and deploy tracking units.
<h3>What We Need &amp

The rains will return to Liuwa Plain National Park in November, which means storks will return and a fishing ban will go into effect in December. December will provide the ideal opportunity to deploy the remaining GPS units on four different Saddlebills. In order to make this happen, we need to raise $4,000 for the expenses associated with returning to the field in Zambia. This will include flights, fuel, camp, and supplies.

Unfortunately, research grants and other funding opportunities are not an option for us because December is so near. So that means we're really counting on the generosity of people who recognize the value of this research! As a thank you to those who donate, we will provide the following perks:

$100: a beautiful Saddlebill Stork t-shirt from RedBubble.com
      $500: 12""x16"" canvas print of your choice from my photo website
      $1,000: name one of the storks we capture and see where it moves!
Without your support in reaching our funding goal, we won't be able to deploy the remaining four GPS units on Saddlebills, so please share with friends and family!
The Impact

By contributing to this project, you are contributing to brand new research that has never been done previously! And, in turn, you are advancing conservation efforts for a charismatic yet neglected species in Africa. By supporting research on Saddlebills, you're supporting conservation of dozens of other wetland species with which storks share their habitat.

Wetlands in Africa -and around the world- are threatened by degradation from damming and pollution, overfishing, and abusive water use. Now more than ever it is critical to understand the ecology of freshwater ecosystems for protecting wildlife and people whose lives rely on these water sources.
<h3>Risks &amp

Field research is risky, especially in the challenging conditions of western Zambia. One obvious risk is the possibility of not capturing any storks. Now that we know what we're doing as far as techniques, I'm confident this won't be an issue. A second risk is that the tracking units we deploy don't work properly. This is always a possibility when working with technology, especially in rough conditions. The units operate using cell phone towers, so it is likely there will be long periods between data downloads -but don't fear, they will transmit data eventually! These challenges and risks are probably one reason no one has attempted this work before -but that makes the outcome all the more exciting and significant!

One alternative to the tracking units we use are GPS-satellite devices, which communicate locations rapidly on a predetermined schedule. These units are much more expensive -about $4,000 USD each- and requires a $30 USD monthly fee for the satellite service. If anyone is interested in sponsoring one of these units to minimize the risks associated with our cellular units, please let us know!
","Short Summary

While lions, rhinos, and elephants gain mainstream attention in African conservation, there are thousands of species that go unnoticed and unstudied, leaving conservationists with no information on which to base conservation efforts. Unfortunately, this is the case with the Saddlebill Stork (Ephippiorhynchus senegalensis), which has been poorly studied. Even with a lack of data, conservationists have assumed Saddlebills are not threatened, which has resulted in low research priority. New research by this team, however, has found that Saddlebills are not as widespread as has been assumed
column2: and that they are mostly confined to national parks.

column1: As a young ecologist I have become concerned about the implications of this narrative and have made it my career goal to fill scientific knowledge gaps to better inform conservation of overlooked species. The story of this project perfectly demonstrates how science should work: I observed Saddlebill Storks in Zambia, asked questions about them, and designed a study to answer those questions. But it also demonstrates how conservation should NOT work: it has a large geographic range, people see it in many places since it's conspicuous, so conservationists assumed it's unthreatened and made up a number for the population size.

While doing carnivore research in Zambia, I saw the Saddlebill and the mystery surrounding it as an opportunity to (1) answer questions for conserving the species and (2) show how the current approach to assessing conservation status can be very inappropriate. I knew it would be an uphill journey to start a field-based project in Africa from scratch, but I was determined. Over the course of two years and three jobs, I realized the Saddlebill could also be used as an umbrella wetland species, which essentially means it could act as a representative for other wildlife with which it shares its wetland habitat. Therefore, by conserving the Saddlebill and its habitat, you would also be positively affecting hundreds of other species.

Against all odds, the logistical and financial challenges of the project were tackled during the two years following inception thanks to the support of many, especially African Bird Club and Texas State University. In June 2019 we had our first field season in which our primary goal was to put GPS tracking units of five Saddlebills for the first time ever. However, the coincidental timing of the worst drought in 40 years meant very few storks were left in the study area in Liuwa Plain National Park, Zambia. The lack of water from the drought also resulted in significant fishing pressure from local people, which caused prey depletion and direct disturbance of the storks. As a result, we only captured one stork and managed to deploy the first tracking unit ever put on a Saddlebill.
Now that we can better anticipate the challenges in the field, we hope to return to Liuwa Plain in December 2019 to capture four more Saddlebills and deploy tracking units.
What We Need & What You Get

The rains will return to Liuwa Plain National Park in November, which means storks will return and a fishing ban will go into effect in December. December will provide the ideal opportunity to deploy the remaining GPS units on four different Saddlebills. In order to make this happen, we need to raise $4,000 for the expenses associated with returning to the field in Zambia. This will include flights, fuel, camp, and supplies.

Unfortunately, research grants and other funding opportunities are not an option for us because December is so near. So that means we're really counting on the generosity of people who recognize the value of this research! As a thank you to those who donate, we will provide the following perks:

$100: a beautiful Saddlebill Stork t-shirt from RedBubble.com      $500: 12""x16"" canvas print of your choice from my photo website      $1,000: name one of the storks we capture and see where it moves!
Without your support in reaching our funding goal, we won't be able to deploy the remaining four GPS units on Saddlebills, so please share with friends and family!
The Impact

By contributing to this project, you are contributing to brand new research that has never been done previously! And, in turn, you are advancing conservation efforts for a charismatic yet neglected species in Africa. By supporting research on Saddlebills, you're supporting conservation of dozens of other wetland species with which storks share their habitat.

Wetlands in Africa -and around the world- are threatened by degradation from damming and pollution, overfishing, and abusive water use. Now more than ever it is critical to understand the ecology of freshwater ecosystems for protecting wildlife and people whose lives rely on these water sources.
Risks & Challenges

Field research is risky, especially in the challenging conditions of western Zambia. One obvious risk is the possibility of not capturing any storks. Now that we know what we're doing as far as techniques, I'm confident this won't be an issue. A second risk is that the tracking units we deploy don't work properly. This is always a possibility when working with technology, especially in rough conditions. The units operate using cell phone towers, so it is likely there will be long periods between data downloads -but don't fear, they will transmit data eventually! These challenges and risks are probably one reason no one has attempted this work before -but that makes the outcome all the more exciting and significant!

One alternative to the tracking units we use are GPS-satellite devices, which communicate locations rapidly on a predetermined schedule. These units are much more expensive -about $4,000 USD each- and requires a $30 USD monthly fee for the satellite service. Twiceys
One t-shirt
Two missions
Mission # 1

Twiceys' mission is to create a good product that helps to raise awareness of how we can make a difference in our environment through small changes in our daily lives. Those changes will be shown in our t-shirts with fun and simple designs.
How it works:

Yes!, I ride my bike to work a couple of days a week! Or, I had changed the incandescent bulbs for CFL ones! And there you have the T-shirt that shows your effort in that direction and in numbers, how your carbon foot-print have become greener. And for those conscious consumers of T-shirts, this is a t-shirt that speaks sustainability by itself!
Our ""inaugural year"" Twicey!
This is the limited edition twicey that was created combinating 4 easy changes. This 4 changes would make us release 10 tons less of CO2 to the atmosphere.
Beyond the T-shirt
Mission # 2
With the sale of each T-shirt, we'll make a concrete change in a kid's life!
From the beginning, we plan to fix a real need in an organization or individual.

We are going to call those  ""fixings"", Twiceys actions. When the need is cover, we'll move to another Twiceys action. Not all the needs are the same so we decided to be flexible. Some kids could need food, others could need winter clothing or shoes.
1st. Twicey action!

We are happy to announce that we have recently became “padrinos.”  In Argentina, where we are originally from, ""padrino"" is a word used to show  when a friend or family member picks you as the best person to give tender loving care for your niece, nephew, o good friend’s kid, etc. in case of their absence or lack of sources).

Through APAER a non-profit organization in Argentina which connects rural schools in need with people commited to mae a difference, we have become padrinos of a Jardin de Infantes (Kindergarten) in a rural isolated part of our dear Argentina, Province of Chaco.

The Jardincito -this is the way the teacher likes to call the place- consists of 24 children (13 girls and 11 boys) from 3 to 5 years old. The kids come from families with several brothers and sisters and are in great need.

The school has electricity and the building is in good shape in comparison with others schools in the area. It does not have running water and must rely on a nearby well, with no pump, so a bucket brings the water up, like in our old days. They need basic Kindergartners material (coloring books, color pencils, etc). In this inaugural year we will be dedicated to address the basic needs of those kids (food, clothing and educational material).

Perhaps the priority for us now is providing regular meals for the children.  The school provides two meals per day (breakfast and lunch) and most of the children rely on these meals as their primary source of nutrition. *18 of the 24 kindergarteners are at risk of malnutrition.

Here comes Twiceys again, through the sale of Twiceys T-shirts, and eventually other accessories in the future, we plan to make an impact into these Kindergarteners lives, the teacher, their family and that rural community at large.
How we’ll do it
We will build a set donation into the cost of the product:
The sale of one T-shirt will provide 20 school meals***

Then through social media, events, etc. we will dedicate our time to let everybody know our story, and how buying a T-shirt you can be part of something bigger and meaningful as changing the lives of those kids in need.
Who We are:

We are a husband and wife team, farm managers at Peacehaven Community Farm in Whitsett NC, where we grow vegetables and community ties, and also the owners of a mini farm-based business called The Farm Fairy. Because our love for growing things, our advocacy for local economies, local food, the environment and the need -like Blake Mycoskie founder of TOMS states- to start something that matters, we have embarked on a dream of having a business with a double purpose.
Our Logo: The guanacos
The guanacos are the wild relatives of the llama, like camels without a hump. They inhabit the arid and semiarid habitats in Argentina where they have their biggest population.
To survive in harsh, dry climates, guanacos have a remarkable ability to conserve water and can obtain moisture from the plants they eat.
They are like the magicians of survival in such harsh environments and because of that particular treat
column2: have inspired us to use it in our logo: two “chulengos” (baby guanacos) looking at different directions and forming a T (for Twiceys) with our beautiful Argentinean landscape in the back.

column1: Our best Ally
The Cotton of the Carolinas
T-shirts
Twiceys Cotton of the Carolinas T-shirts
* breath North Carolina air
* have been kissed by North Carolina sunshine
* and been made by North Carolinian hands.
600 miles from cotton field to printed/dyed shirt creating from farmers to manufacturers 500 jobs in the process.
100% North Carolina-grown cotton.
Made entirely, dirt-to-shirt in North Carolina, entirely traceable supply chain, every shirt has a code that the wearer can use to see every member of the supply chain that made his or her product.
Nothing can beat the transparency of this product!
<h2 style=""margin-left: 30px
column2: >For our project to hatch we need your help!

column1: Twiceys has started as a need to put words into actions and for that we will need a little push, we need to raise some money and that is the reason we are here in Indiegogo.
The funds from this Indiegogo project go to:
-Raise money to call for 4 contests among graphic designers in order to have our first 4 designs ready to print in our new line of shirts.
-Raise capital for shirt production: our goal amount enables us to order the minimum number of shirts per color to get the best possible bulk price break.
-Printing a run of stickers
With this inventory, we’ll be prepared to approach the world outside!
Of course the more support we get, the more we can make and the more we can help others. Every additional support beyond our goal will go towards more designs and additional T-shirts.
Keep in mind that this campaign is all-or-nothing. If we don't reach the goal we don't get any money (all the money goes back to the founders, you).
Even when the money is not released until the last day, the sooner we reach the goal the better.
Next steps:
<ol>
• press the ""contribute now"" button,
• contribute!,
• spread the word (really important!)
• we'll keep in touch with updates!
Thank you in advance!

The Alberta Tar Sands are possibly the most environmentally significant site of our time: a symbolic battleground in the fight for the future of our planet against climate change
column2: a violation of the rights of indigenous people
column3: a threat to one of the oldest, most robust and diverse ecosystems in the world: the boreal rain forest. On July 5th - 6th, First Nations tribes and Canadian activists will walk alongside the Tar Sands with a message of peace, compassion and healing. We're raising money to see that NYC is there walking along with them.

column1: As Brooklyn-based climate justice activists, we've organized buses for this year's Forward On Climate rally in Washington, D.C, contributed writing to the Sierra Club NYC blog and helped launch a fossil fuel divestment campaign for the CUNY university system. This new campaign, the Tar Sands Healing Walk - NYC Contingent, is a way for New Yorkers concerned about climate change and environmental injustice to show a concrete form of solidarity with the frontline community that is taking the toxic brunt of the Tar Sands.

Your donation will enable four activists to travel by car from New York to Fort McMurray, Alberta, CN - a 5,000 mile roundtrip trek - to walk alongside First Nations, Metis and Inuit people in the annual Tar Sands Healing Walk. Using social media throughout our journey, we aim to raise awareness about the injustices of the Tar Sands and to inspire the NYC community to intensify their own commitment to the movement to stop climate change. Upon returning to NYC, we will host a presentation to report-back to the community all that we saw and experienced.

We hope to raise $1,500 (or more) to help us offset the rental cost for a hybrid vehicle, fuel fill-ups, food, tolls and other miscellaneous travel expenses. For a donation of $10, we will write you a personalized tweet of thanks for your contribution. For a donation of $30, we will send you a personalized postcard from a destination en route to the Tar Sands. For $50, we will make you a big jar of delicious, organic maple-coconut granola. For a donation of $100 - $300, you can have a private 45-minute concert in your very own home by climate/folk singer-songwriter, San Joaquin. For $300 - $400, Galicia, one of the activists riding with us, will perform a fire poi show! For a donation of $500 or more, you get a free 2-hour surf lesson by me, long-time surfer and former ocean lifeguard, AND get to hang out at a beautiful East Hampton beach all day on a Saturday or a Sunday this summer or fall, your choice.

The Tar Sands Healing Walk is a unique nonviolent direct action organized by Keepers of the Athabasca, and is not like other political rallies. Participants are asked not to raise signs or wave banners, but rather to bear witness to the beauty and power of the land, and to stand in peace and compassion before the heinous environmental crimes that are the tar sands mining and processing sites.

With your donation, you are helping to build real connections between New York City climate activists and Canadian First Nations people who have been suffering for decades at the hands of powerful fossil fuel corporations. The experiences we share with the local community of the Athabasca river basin, we in turn share with our network of NYC activists, which in turn reinvigorates our efforts here in New York to stop climate change
column2: to stop the building of natural gas pipelines
column3: to divest our universities' and other institutional endowments from fossil fuel stocks
column4: to promote the advancement of carbon-free energy and modes of sustainable living
column5: to fight for equitable disaster preparedness and relief. Every facet of the work we do as climate activists is enhanced by making contact with the Tar Sands and by sharing in the struggles of the front-line community there.

column1: If you can't contribute monetarily to our cause, but you believe in what we're doing, please spread the word in any way you can. Thanks for reading.
Sincerely,
Dan Asselin
Organizer: CUNY Divest &
column2: New York Students For Fossil Fuel Divestment

What is PeTrak?

PeTrak is a GPS based electronic pet fencing system.  By employing the Global Positioning System it is the only fencing product that utilizes a true positioning technology that, in concert with the latest sensors, a powerful microprocessor, and proprietary software, results in a revolutionary improvement over existing fencing products. Everything about PeTrak, from the basic concept and hardware to the custom software, was driven by our desire to create the most reliable and versatile pet fence possible. Although you may have seen one of the many so called GPS pet trackers in recent years those are not fencing systems and they are fraught with problems. See the section below on all competitive products.

In the past the most popular fencing system was the buried wire fence invented way back in the mid 70's. They employed proximity sensing and were very effective at keeping your pet within a boundary created by burying a wire in the ground. However, if your dog decided to ""run through"" the boundary all control was lost and your dog was free to run as far and for as long as it wanted. Worse yet all buried wire fences actually prevent your pet from returning to your yard since they cannot distinguish which side of the fence the dog is actually on. Wireless fences (based on detecting a radio signal) were never very successful being limited to a small circle and having to be centered where the controller could be plugged into a power outlet. They also lose control after a run through and then shut down until the customer re-initializes the controller and collar. The new WiFi fences are based on the communication protocol that allows us to use our laptop computers at local coffee shops.  They are expensive, complicated to set up, and have a limited effective range after a run through.

From your pet's point of view PeTrak operates in a similar manner discouraging your pet from leaving the boundary that is established around your property. So far it sounds like most of the other fencing products.  This was deliberate on our part so that any of these other systems could easily be replaced with PeTrak.  However the similarities end there.  As a do-it-yourself (DIY) project PeTrak allows a pet owner to create a virtual boundary around their yard using only the PeTrak collar and a clip-on Programming Fixture that comes with every unit. Simply by walking that boundary and pausing briefly at every vertex (anywhere the boundary changes directions, indicated by those yellow arrows in the illustration below) and pushing a button on the Programming Fixture you can create a fence. You can alter your fence in the future or, if you move, you can create an entirely new one at your new home.  You can conveniently use your PeTrak fence at other locations. Whether you set up PeTrak yourself, or utilize the services of one of our professional dealers,there are no controllers to install, wires to bury, costly trenching, driveway cutting, or obstacles that are impassable.  Most importantly, PeTrak never loses control.
How Does It Work?

PeTrak utilizes the Global Positioning Satellite system, or GPS, to create a virtual fence and monitor the position and activity of your pet. Is that all there is to it? Hardly, and we have five years of work, two patents and four pending patent applications to prove it. Selecting GPS was the easy part, how and what to do with the position and velocity data is something else entirely. But basically, once a fence is created the collar keeps track of your pet (so we call it PeTrak) and its activity. The only time the collar is fully active is when it determines that your pet will leave the boundary within a specific time limit. That’s because PeTrak is not a proximity fence like most others. What is important is not how close your pet is to the boundary but rather how fast he or she may be moving towards it. If a breach is imminent, then the collar will warn first and only correct if necessary. If a breach should occur PeTrak is the only fencing system that never loses control or shuts down. PeTrak switches from the normal fencing protocol to an advanced algorithm that tracks, monitors and reacts to your pet's behavior to slow it down and safely return it to the boundary.
No other fence keeps working to keep your pet safe and return it to your yard.
Second Programmable Boundary

PeTrak is capable of storing a secondary boundary that you can program as easily as the first using the Programming Fixture.  If you have a vacation home or often take your dog to grandma's house you can create a boundary there in addition to the one at home.  PeTrak will automatically recognize  either boundary when activated within it.     What could be easier or more convenient?
Park Zone

We created the Park Zone function for use anywhere you might want to let your dog run, but now without worrying if he will stray too far.  The boundary is circular and you can quickly set the size.  Using the Key Fob you set the boundary center where you're standing.  Then set the size in 50 foot increments.  It's as easy as that!
Where Are We Today?

Our first two patents have been granted.  With another four pending applications our intellectual property is well protected. Several working models, one of which is pictured below, have been tested and performed extremely well. The next step is  completing the industrial engineering
column2: designing the various plastic parts, ordering production tooling, and reducing the circuit board from prototype size (shown below) to production size.   The size reduction will make it comfortable and easy for a pet to wear.  PeTrak will be the same size and lighter than competitive buried wire fences.

column1: How Will The Funds Be Used?

With your support, funds will be used for the work described above, to purchase tooling and other capital equipment, continue our patent work, and to put PeTrak into production and take it to market. Our local manufacturer in Pennsylvania is ready to produce the electronics and assemble early production. A large turnkey manufacturer in New York will produce our products in high volume, packaged and ready to ship.  We are looking for a second source manufacturer in the Carolina's and are talking with a plastics manufacturer in New Jersey to source both tooling and injection molded parts.
Below are selected pages from our Competitive Analysis.
PeTrak Dealers

For those interested to become authorized dealers we have designed and patented a unique set of tools to facilitate the design and programming of a custom boundary layout which can be viewed on a map or satellite image of the customer's property.  The Self Survey Stakes shown below automatically generate the most accurate boundary data possible while you perform the dog training sessions.  We will also teach you our proprietary low stress training method.  Your time on the job is dramatically lower than with buried wire systems as is your startup cost.  Best of all will be your customer's overall satisfaction and the referrals that will come with it.
Dealer Startup Equipment is shown below.  Laptop included, not shown.
About Us

Our team at PeTrak comprises electronic, mechanical and software engineers. John and Bill each have over 25 years of corporate management, engineering and product design and development experience with firms including Leviton Mfg., Lutron Electronics, Flexlink and Huntington Automated Systems. Dan and Dave each bring more than 20 years of engineering experience, and a proven expertise in GPS technology, to the project.
PeTrak is an American based small business that is committed to building quality products in the USA. We pledge to keep our R&
column2: D, Manufacturing, Sales and Service here in America and to source any and all available parts domestically. PeTrak products will proudly display that they are ""Made in America"".

column1: FAQ
Q. Do I ever have to replace the batteries? A. No.  PeTrak employs the best available Lithium-ion battery technology and comes with a charger.
Q. How long does the battery charge last? A. This depends on your dogs’ activity but is typically one week.

Q. How will I know if the battery needs recharging?  A. PeTrak will announce the need to recharge well in advance.  The LED on the collar will start flashing red and there is a flashing red low battery LED on the charger.  You can also set the charger to announce a low battery with an audible alert.
Q. Is it waterproof? A. Yes.  Your pet can go swimming, run in the rain etc.
Q. Can I use PeTrak with my small dog? A. PeTrak is as small as competitive products and is actually lighter than many of them.  It can be used with any dog 10 lbs. or greater.
Q. Does PeTrak have a warranty? A. Yes, PeTrak is covered by a limited lifetime warranty.
Q. Are there any monthly fees with PeTrak like some competitive products.        A. No, there are no monthly or activation fees.

Q. What if I want to turn the collar off? A. Each PeTrak system includes a Key Fob that when held against a visible target on the collar unit will disable or enable the unit.  The collar can also be controlled from the charger unit in your home.  With the addition of an optional device and an App we will introduce in the second quarter of next year you will also be able to use your Smartphone.
Q. What if I move? A. Your PeTrak system is completely portable and can be reprogrammed to a new home location in the same manner as originally set up.
Q. What if I have a vacation home? A. PeTrak is capable of storing two boundaries.  Once programmed, the collar will recognize either location when enabled.

Q. What about temporary use. A. The PeTrak Park Zone feature allows you to set up a temporary circular boundary anywhere in a few moments with the Key Fob.  Normal operation resumes when you return home.

Q. What is ""Run-Through""? A. Run-Through is when a dog ""runs through"" a virtual boundary.  This can occur with any fencing system, including PeTrak, when your pet sees something compelling outside the boundary such as a deer.  The critical difference is that only PeTrak keeps working to protect and safely return your pet.

Q. What is the Key Fob? A. The Key Fob is a small accessory you can attach to your key ring or leash to enable or disable the PeTrak collar.  This function can also be accessed from the charger unit or with an optional accessory and free app through your smartphone.
Q. Can I replace the collar strap? A. Yes, however the straps are specially made for PeTrak and cannot be substituted with off the shelf pet collars.

Q. How does PeTrak compare with other virtual fencing products on the market? A. PeTrak is lower cost, better performing and offers far more features than any other product on the market.  For detailed comparison information see the section on Competitive Products.

Q. If I already have an electronic fence can I replace it with PeTrak?          A. Yes.  From your pet's point of view, PeTrak is backward compatible with all competitive fencing products.   Just program PeTrak with the same boundaries and replace the old collar with the new PeTrak collar

Q. I am an overseas supporter.  Can I use PeTrak where I live?  A. Yes, PeTrak can be used anywhere on the globe.  Boundary accuracy may vary somewhat beyond the continental U.S.  Please specify where you intend to use PeTrak in order to receive a charger power pack with the appropriate wall plug and operating voltage.

Q. Can I only contribute through PayPal? A. Indiegogo limits contributions through PayPal but you can pay with your own credit card, as a guest, through PayPal up to $500.  http://support.indiegogo.com/entries/20501786-how-to-contribute-via-paypal-without-a-paypal-account

Q. What if my contribution is greater than $500? A. You can make multiple payments as a guest or you can easily set up a PayPal account.  http://support.indiegogo.com/entries/20492908-how-to-set-up-your-paypal-account
","What is PeTrak?

PeTrak is a GPS based electronic pet fencing system.  By employing the Global Positioning System it is the only fencing product that utilizes a true positioning technology that, in concert with the latest sensors, a powerful microprocessor, and proprietary software, results in a revolutionary improvement over existing fencing products. Everything about PeTrak, from the basic concept and hardware to the custom software, was driven by our desire to create the most reliable and versatile pet fence possible. Although you may have seen one of the many so called GPS pet trackers in recent years those are not fencing systems and they are fraught with problems. See the section below on all competitive products.

In the past the most popular fencing system was the buried wire fence invented way back in the mid 70's. They employed proximity sensing and were very effective at keeping your pet within a boundary created by burying a wire in the ground. However, if your dog decided to ""run through"" the boundary all control was lost and your dog was free to run as far and for as long as it wanted. Worse yet all buried wire fences actually prevent your pet from returning to your yard since they cannot distinguish which side of the fence the dog is actually on. Wireless fences (based on detecting a radio signal) were never very successful being limited to a small circle and having to be centered where the controller could be plugged into a power outlet. They also lose control after a run through and then shut down until the customer re-initializes the controller and collar. The new WiFi fences are based on the communication protocol that allows us to use our laptop computers at local coffee shops.  They are expensive, complicated to set up, and have a limited effective range after a run through.

From your pet's point of view PeTrak operates in a similar manner discouraging your pet from leaving the boundary that is established around your property. So far it sounds like most of the other fencing products.  This was deliberate on our part so that any of these other systems could easily be replaced with PeTrak.  However the similarities end there.  As a do-it-yourself (DIY) project PeTrak allows a pet owner to create a virtual boundary around their yard using only the PeTrak collar and a clip-on Programming Fixture that comes with every unit. Simply by walking that boundary and pausing briefly at every vertex (anywhere the boundary changes directions, indicated by those yellow arrows in the illustration below) and pushing a button on the Programming Fixture you can create a fence. You can alter your fence in the future or, if you move, you can create an entirely new one at your new home.  You can conveniently use your PeTrak fence at other locations. Whether you set up PeTrak yourself, or utilize the services of one of our professional dealers,there are no controllers to install, wires to bury, costly trenching, driveway cutting, or obstacles that are impassable.  Most importantly, PeTrak never loses control.
How Does It Work?

PeTrak utilizes the Global Positioning Satellite system, or GPS, to create a virtual fence and monitor the position and activity of your pet. Is that all there is to it? Hardly, and we have five years of work, two patents and four pending patent applications to prove it. Selecting GPS was the easy part, how and what to do with the position and velocity data is something else entirely. But basically, once a fence is created the collar keeps track of your pet (so we call it PeTrak) and its activity. The only time the collar is fully active is when it determines that your pet will leave the boundary within a specific time limit. That’s because PeTrak is not a proximity fence like most others. What is important is not how close your pet is to the boundary but rather how fast he or she may be moving towards it. If a breach is imminent, then the collar will warn first and only correct if necessary. If a breach should occur PeTrak is the only fencing system that never loses control or shuts down. PeTrak switches from the normal fencing protocol to an advanced algorithm that tracks, monitors and reacts to your pet's behavior to slow it down and safely return it to the boundary.
No other fence keeps working to keep your pet safe and return it to your yard.
Second Programmable Boundary

PeTrak is capable of storing a secondary boundary that you can program as easily as the first using the Programming Fixture.  If you have a vacation home or often take your dog to grandma's house you can create a boundary there in addition to the one at home.  PeTrak will automatically recognize  either boundary when activated within it.     What could be easier or more convenient?
Park Zone

We created the Park Zone function for use anywhere you might want to let your dog run, but now without worrying if he will stray too far.  The boundary is circular and you can quickly set the size.  Using the Key Fob you set the boundary center where you're standing.  Then set the size in 50 foot increments.  It's as easy as that!
Where Are We Today?

Our first two patents have been granted.  With another four pending applications our intellectual property is well protected. Several working models, one of which is pictured below, have been tested and performed extremely well. The next step is  completing the industrial engineering

Our local manufacturer in Pennsylvania is ready to produce the electronics and assemble early production. A large turnkey manufacturer in New York will produce our products in high volume, packaged and ready to ship.  We are looking for a second source manufacturer in the Carolina's and are talking with a plastics manufacturer in New Jersey to source both tooling and injection molded parts.
Below are selected pages from our Competitive Analysis.
PeTrak Dealers

For those interested to become authorized dealers we have designed and patented a unique set of tools to facilitate the design and programming of a custom boundary layout which can be viewed on a map or satellite image of the customer's property.  The Self Survey Stakes shown below automatically generate the most accurate boundary data possible while you perform the dog training sessions.  We will also teach you our proprietary low stress training method.  Your time on the job is dramatically lower than with buried wire systems as is your startup cost.  Best of all will be your customer's overall satisfaction and the referrals that will come with it.
Dealer Startup Equipment is shown below.  Laptop included, not shown.
About Us

Our team at PeTrak comprises electronic, mechanical and software engineers. John and Bill each have over 25 years of corporate management, engineering and product design and development experience with firms including Leviton Mfg., Lutron Electronics, Flexlink and Huntington Automated Systems. Dan and Dave each bring more than 20 years of engineering experience, and a proven expertise in GPS technology, to the project.

PeTrak is an American based small business that is committed to building quality products in the USA. We pledge to keep our R&D, Manufacturing, Sales and Service here in America and to source any and all available parts domestically. PeTrak products will proudly display that they are ""Made in America"".

What am I doing?

Hello internet community! First of all THANK YOU so much for taking the time to read this! My name is Sarah Curtis. I am 34 years old and live in Salt Lake City, Utah. My goal is to raise enough funding to go and pursue my life’s dream of becoming a Law Enforcement Park Ranger for the National Park Service. The first step to making this dream a reality is to attend the Northern Arizona University’s Park Ranger Training Program. The program is 3 months long in Flagstaff, Arizona and includes the 400 hour National Park Service Seasonal Law Enforcement Training Program that is required in order to obtain a position as a Law Enforcement Ranger for the Park Service. This is something I have always wanted to do but never knew how I could afford to do it. Recently I was blindsided when I lost my job. I didn’t see it coming at all, but I’ve decided that instead of having a pity party for myself that I am going to turn this into something positive. Losing my job is going to be the best thing that’s ever happened to me!
Why do I want to do this?

I truly love our National Parks and want to do everything I can to ensure that they are still here and protected for our future generations. I want to serve and protect these national treasures and devote myself to them. Growing up, my family would load up the station wagon (Griswald style) every summer and we would go to National Parks as our annual trip. Our family trips weren’t fancy and usually we were pretty much roughing it but the memories I have and the experiences are my happiest.  I want to make sure that other people can experience the magnificence and wonder of these very special places and hopefully get to create happy memories like I’ve been fortunate enough too.
What I Need &

I wish that I had the money that I need to do this on my own without becoming broke and losing everything but unfortunately I don't. My goal with this campaign is to raise $8,785.00. All of the money raised will go towards the program fees, travel, housing, and living expenses. Here is a more detailed breakdown of the costs.
<ul>
• Program fee: $4,500
• Application fee: $150
• Class fee: $385.00
• Travel fuel: $200.00
• Housing in Flagstaff, AZ: $2,850.00 ($950/month x’s 3 months)

I know that this is a lot of money to ask for! I don’t how else I could make this dream a reality without your help. I’ve worked hard and have had at least one job, sometimes two, but have never been able to save enough up to attend this program. Your donation is all I got to make this happen. This opportunity is incredibly important to me and it will be a forever life-changing experience. I realize that I will have to make great sacrifices to make this happen and I am in it for the long hull. I can not wait to go through this program and finally be able to do my part to protect our National Parks and share my stories with you.
Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to donate, that's okay too, you can still help though! Get the word out! Share with your friends and family. Please post my campaign on Facebook, twitter, or email it to others. Whatever you can do will help me make my dreams come true!
